Show HN: RepeatGPT – Schedule recurring ChatGPT executions
text:
Hey HN community! I'm excited to share my latest project with you - RepeatGPT, a web app that allows you to schedule recurring executions of ChatGPT and receive the results via email.

Here's how it works: You simply provide a prompt or question to ChatGPT, select a frequency and time for the executions (e.g. daily at 9am), and enter your email address. RepeatGPT takes care of the rest, running the ChatGPT model on the specified schedule and sending you the generated text via email.

Some fun example prompts: - Daily: Give me an inspirational quote - Weekly: Give me 10 uncommon Spanish words and their english translation - Daily: Here are 7 tasks: Monday - Research LLMs, …. Give me today's task and 5 bullet points on how to achieve it.

Really, your imagination is the limit! Can't wait to see what you'll come up with. =)

Please give RepeatGPT a try and let me know what you think! I'm happy to answer any questions or feedback you may have.

title: Ask HN: Should-we open-source our meeting bot?
text:
We've created a meeting bot that integrates with the 3 major meeting platforms (Zoom / Teams / Microsoft Teams), and then gives users: - the transcript, - a ChatGPT summary, - the video recording - avideo-reel of the meeting higlights, along with GPT summaries of the meeting highlights.

=> https://spoke.app

Unfortunately, due to various reasons, we haven't had the success we hoped for, although the sector in general (AI video meeting assistants) was and is still booming.

One reason why we often failed to convince companies were privacy and security reasons.

1. Do you think companies could be easier to convince as regards security if the main aspects of the app were open-source?

2. Do you think that by open-sourcing our meeting bot, we could be the "pick and shovel" for this new AI assistant meeting boom? What potential risks and benefits do you see to that?

Ask HN: What is formula for karma per comment?
text:
Trying to figure out how to accurately get the average karma per comment and appears it is not possible.

(For example, karma for posts and comments is merged together — but quick Google appears to show karma points for posts are calculated as the number of upvotes a given user's content has received minus the number of downvotes; since HN hides downvotes, appears it’s impossible to separate karma from submissions and comments.)

Am I missing something?

Show HN: kingbit, an online asynchronous multiplayer game like chess, for iOS
text:
Download Link: https://apps.apple.com/app/id1565583669

"kingbit" combines two of my favourite games: The Nightfall Incident and chess. I usually describe it to people by telling them: "it's like chess, but the pieces can take up multiple squares"

The game is quick to learn and quick to play... a full match is about 5-10 minutes.

If you like "Really Bad Chess", "Pawnbarian" or "Hero Academy" (RIP), I think you'll really enjoy it.

You can see an example of some game play here: https://v.redd.it/6i08fjezl5la1

And you can learn more about the game here: https://old.reddit.com/r/kingbit/

Excited for you try it out! And more excited to play some of you (Game Center: emehex)

Ask HN: Thoughts on Object-Oriented Databases?
text:
Yesterday, I built a fully functional OODB prototype called Objective DB with Python. I will soon deploy it as a (post/page) storage solution on a custom/self-hosted CMS for testing.

Does anyone have any experience working with or on OO databases? Do you have any links/resources that address the topic in detail?

Any input would be appreciated. Thanks!

Ask HN: Could Generative AI Improve Compilers?
text:
With the growing popularity of generative AI I have thought what real world topics could it address (I know art is important but I mean engineering uses). What would be the outcome if we could train a model to generate compilers for new or existing syntaxes. I have not pursued this idea but thought it might be an interesting conversation to be had.

The main issue I can imagine is there is a relatively small training data set that could be used. Also, we see that tools like ChatGPT struggle with understanding (tackling physics problems etc).

Wondering what peoples thoughts are about this or if its a stupid idea.
